snippet.title: Q&A: Noting and Clinging
snippet.description:
To ask questions and join our community, please visit http://meditation.sirimangalo.org/
To support our work, please visit http://www.sirimangalo.org/support/

Question in this video:
I've been using the 5 aggregates to note experiences I have during meditation, an itch is noted as form/feeling, thought of work/family as formation, etc, obviously, all experiences are developed through multiple aggregates, but, would you think that this noting technique could encourage clinging to the aggregates rather than helping observe their impermanence?  Also, while using this technique, they are always connected to a hindrance/fetter, which quickly makes it apparent that all experience is wrapped in hindrance/fetter, I know this exhibits the hindrance of doubt, but, this seems short sighted?

Re-upload of Q&A session by Bhante Yuttadhammo; June 8, 2019.

.

snippet.title: Q&A: Mindfulness and Noting
snippet.description:
To ask questions and join our community, please visit http://meditation.sirimangalo.org/
To support our work, please visit http://www.sirimangalo.org/support/

Question in this video:
Can multiple meditation objects form a single object that can be noted? For example, I suffer from fairly severe anxiety. During meditation, when I try to note the anxiety, I find that the feeling of anxiety coincides with repetitive thoughts about the things that bring me anxiety. I note both the thinking and the feeling of anxiety as a single meditation object and say to myself "anxious, anxious..." Is this incorrect practice? I struggle to understand how the mind handles the different components of reality. It seems like while the mind is aware of one component, it also has a "background awareness" of the other components since we are able to divert our attention to any of the other components. If this is the case, couldn't we just note all objects at once? Furthermore, is there any relationship between numbers and absolute reality? If the mind can only be aware of one thing at once, is the number 1 the only number that exists? Clarification would be greatly appreciated. Thank you.

Re-upload of Q&A session by Bhante Yuttadhammo; May 13, 2019.

.

snippet.title: Q&A: Peaceful Meditation
snippet.description:
To ask questions and join our community, please visit http://meditation.sirimangalo.org/
To support our work, please visit http://www.sirimangalo.org/support/

Question in this video:
Could you talk a bit about how mindfulness can be restful? I find a lot that I become distracted and pulled into a sort of comfortable unconscious haze. I’d like to be able to reside in the present throughout my day, though it can be quite exhausting, because mindfulness is a difficult thing. Yet I see spiritual teachers who are very at ease and rested in the present moment. What leads to their ability to do this, and how do I know that I am going in the right direction?

Re-upload of Q&A session by Bhante Yuttadhammo; Dec 26, 2018.

.

Question in this video:
After I do meditation in the afternoon I go out of my room and I take food with some people but I have notice that I have a lot of concentration and they tell me I look like if I'm on drugs and I tried to be "normal" but if I talk my head starts to hurt and I start to shake like a bell and I have a lot of sweating, especially in the hands and this is everyday and I'm kind of embarrassed, in general is difficult to deal with people after I meditate but I don't think going to a cave is a solution... any recommendation? Thanks!

snippet.description:

To support our work, please visit http://www.sirimangalo.org/support/

Verse 2 in Pāḷi 2: Yamaka

manopubbaṅgamā dhammā,
manoseṭṭhā manomayā,
manasā ce pasannena
bhāsati vā karoti vā,
tato naṁ sukham anveti
chāyā va anapāyinī.

The background story can be found here:
https://what-buddha-said.net/Canon/Sutta/KN/Dhammapada.htm#Twin%20Pairs%20-%20Yamaka

snippet.title: Unshaken
snippet.description:
To ask questions and join our community, please visit http://meditation.sirimangalo.org/
To support our work, please visit http://www.sirimangalo.org/support/

Dhammatalk on the eight loka­dhamma: gain (lābho), loss (alābho), popularity (yaso), unpopularity (ayaso), blame (nindā), praise (pasaṃsā), happiness (sukha), suffering (dukkha).

Re-upload of dhammatalk from June 16, 2018.

Here is a discourse on the worldly vicissitudes by Mahāsi Sayādaw: http://www.aimwell.org/lokadhamma.html.

.
